div2.stage: Carefull pulling in Emilia in Boys Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: WHo the Devil have we here? Nay, nay Sir, I must see your Face; another Gallant of my Daughter's I warrant! Who are you Sir, from whence come you, what Business have you in my House, ha?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Oh Lord, what shall I say to this old Fellow, he'll certainly know me.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: What are you studying for a Lye Sir? Adod I shall make you find your Tongue, speak quickly or I'll cut your Throat (Draws.) you Dog you.
Ah! Oh Lord a Sword! For Heavens sake Sir, Oh Lord Sir don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Know you Sir? who the Pox are you Sir, ha? Emilia, why what Masquerade's this? Where's my Daughter.
Ho Sir, your Humble Servant, why what a Pox are you going into the Service; you are two pretty Volunteers faith.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha! my Father, what shall I say,—I'll e'en face it out since he has catc'd me; we have done a Friend of yours some Service Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: A Friend of mine! As how, pray forsooth?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why you must know Sir I was inform'd of a Duel between Sir William Mode, and a Brother Beau of his; the concern I knew you had for Sir William's safety, engag'd my Care for the Prevention; I was unwilling to Expose him, by sending any body else, so that my Cousin and I, by the help of this Disguise, pated them; but we shou'd not need to have made such haste, for the Puppits was trying their Valour safely with a couple of Files, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, And this was the occasion of your being in Breeches, ha?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And I think it a good project too Uncle.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: You do,—Well Daughter pray let's have you in your Feminine Capacity again; for though you Bully in Breeches, I hope you'll Marry in Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Cia.
sp.p: Marry Sir!

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, I have sent for Sir William, in order to have the settlement compleated to Night, and to Morrow your Honour shall rise with the Sun; that is to say, you shall be my Lady Mode.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Honour Sir, where's the Honour of such a Husband? I hope Sir you will not Marry me to a Coward; why there's not a needy Bully about Town but will beat a Maintenance out of him, and where is the Reputation of such a Marriage.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: But he'll make a swinging Jointure, and if you don't like him when you have him, you may live apart.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Heaven what shall I say,—Sir I beg you but delay your purpose for a Month.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Not for a Day.—

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sir I have sworn not to Marry this Month.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Have you so, pray who have you swora to Mistress, to Mr. Ogle, ha?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ogle, who is he pray Sir?—Heaven, has my Father got this Story too!

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: You don't know such a Person I'll warrant you as Mr. Ogle?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I have seen such a Fellow Sir, but never spoke to him.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: No—look in my Face,—You never spoke to him, that is, encourag'd his Love?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: No—Upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: —You lie, you have no Honour, read that, (throws her the Letter) and do you hear, resolve to marry Sir William to morrow Morning by six, or I'll Marry my self before Twelve; so take your choice. I'll Ogle you, and Soldier you with a Pox to you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Impudence from Ogle, I'll have the Rascal tost in a Blanket; see Emilia what an audacious Letter tis, bless me, I have no Patience; I encourage such a Rascal.—

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: He is very familiar methinks—hang him, the Fool's below your Anger, never think on't; come prethee think which way to turn your self if the Colionel be false, as I dare swear he is. What think you of Marrying Sir William, he is Master of a fair Estate, which you may make subservient to your Pleasures, to makē Life's rugged Journey pass the smoother. If he be true, as you have but little reason to think he is, you may yet find some way to accomplish your desires. Come the time draws on in which you'll be convinc'd of his Truth or Falshhood.

l.hi: Come what will, resolve to be content,
And trust to Fortune for the wish'd Event.

div2.stage: Enter Careful, Toper, and Mrs. Plotwell, drest like a Quaker.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mr. Toper, Your Cousin is welcome, my House is at your Service Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I thank thee, but pray thee do not Madam me, my name is Anne.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: A very handsome Womand, and very modestly drest.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I have us'd all the Arguments in my Power to Convert her from this Formality, but in vain, she's as averse to the Fashions, as other Women are fond of 'em; but I hope your Neice and Daughter will work a Reformation in her.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: I rather hope she'll work one in them, I'll assure you I'll recommend her as a Patron. Is this the woman you would recommend to me for a Wife Mr. Toper.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: The same Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: I protest I like her exceedingly she seems, cut out on purpose for me; her plain way of Living will improve my Estate, and her Morals will hamper my Daughter, I like a Religious Woman.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: You can't be better match'd, if she has not too much; yesterday I carried her to wait on a Relation of ours that has a Parrot, and whilst I was discoursing about some private Business, she converted the Bird, and now it talks of nothing but the Light of the Spirit, and the inward Man. Ha, ha. Caref. Good lack, good lack.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Well, well, thee wilt never leave thy rediculous Jests; I say that Mankind were not made for Foppery and Pride, but to do good in their Generation,—Prethee shew me one Text of Scripture for the Fashions, or where Jewels are commanded, or what Holy Matron ever had a Valet, to dress 'em, as they say the French Ladies have, Oh monstrous Fashion!—No no, our devoutest Women wore course Linnen, or rather none at all.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ay, such Saints as wore their Congregations without side, and swarm'd with Christian Vermin, it must be them, ha, ha, ha, but you hold every handsome Garment a Sin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Handsome Garment! Verily I believe, if we are punish'd with Taxes again to carry on another War, 'twill be a just Judgment upon this sinful Land for their full Wiggs, Favourites, Furbelows, false Teeth, and Patches.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Truly I'm of her opinion, she speaks like an Oracle, for the Devil was never so Proud as our Women are now a days, (Aside.) I am resolv'd, if my Daughter shew the least relunctance to my will, to Marry her out of hand. I'll motion it to her, and try how she likes me.— (aside.) What think you of a Husband forsooth, for to be plain with you, your extraordinary qualities have rais'd a great desire in me of becoming such.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I doubt Friend thoul't expect a larger Fortune than I am Dame of.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: I protest I don't care if you have not a Groat, your Vertue's a wealthy Dowry to me, say you'll but have me, and 'tis enough;

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: But it may be thou'lt be against my course of Life; I love Retirement, must have time for my Devotion in my own way; I'm not us'd to the Ceremony of Visits, and hate Tea-Table Vanity, and Card-play, as they call it. Toper. Our Plot takes rarely. (Aside.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: This makes me love you the more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: One thing more; Thou hast a Daughter they say, a topping Gallant, which I desire to see, and try if good Admonitions, together with Example, wont reform her; for plainly I dont care to come under the Roof where Children are, if they be not dutiful, so that I must see her first e're I can give thee my Answer.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: That you shall presently—Here carry this Gentlewoman to my Daughter and tell her, she must entertain her as her Mother that is to be, tell her so from me, d'ye hear.
Really Mr. Toper, Your Cousin is a profound Christian, if my Daughter refuse to Marry Sir William,—I'll Jointure her in my whole Estate.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: For ought I know, You can't do better than Marry; for who who would be plagu'd with a disobedient Child?

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Especially when they depend upon us for their Fortunes, the Devil a Young Fellow would care a Souce for their Persons, did not our Purse-strings draw. Here forsooth my Daughter is running mad after a Soldier, a Fellow whose Fortunes depend upon his Sword, and here we are going to Wars again, and six to four but a Cannon-Bullet takes his Head off, and then the Wife is turn'd home to her Father again, and in such Cases a Father has never dispos'd of his Children entirely, and all the Jointure shee'll bring, will consist of Housings, Holster-Caps, Pistols, and Swords.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here's Sir William Mode below Sir.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Tell him I'll wait on him presently. Come Mr. Toper, you shall be witness of our Agreement; I sent for him to compleat the Business, Sign Seal to Night, and to Morrow we'll have a Dance.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I fancy we shall drive Dancing out of your Head, Old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: WEll, in my Conscience the first sight of you frighted me horribly, though I knew your Plot, I vow you make a sanctified Figure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Might I pass upon the Brethren think you?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Ay, and hold forth too I'll warrant you, without being discover'd. But is my Uncle so hot upon Matrimony say you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: As a hound upon the Scent, tho' he'll share no more of the Pleasure, than the Dog of the Game he runs down, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I vow I can't help laughing to think what a trick we shall put upon him,—but the duce on't I cannot be heartily merry till I se Event of this Meeting; I long till the Collonel comes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: So do I as much as you, to upbraid him with his Treachery.
In my Conscience he's here,—show him into my Chamber, tell him Ill wait on him presently,—Now Clarinda you shall go in myplace.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Heaven! how I tremble. Oh the Perfidious Wreteh, sure he's
quite lost to Vertue, that he dares thus impudently venture into the very House. Oh give me Patience Heaven, and Power to back my Resolution, and Scorn enough to show my deep Resentment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I'll to the Old Man, and keep him in Discourse, that he mayn't interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Do so,—I must listen a little to hear what Reception she gives him.

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p: This Love makes Men the Errantest Asses in the World, what blustering Mars with all his Steely Garranture of War cou'd never do, this blind Boy does with a Feather'd Reed. Oh my Soul, I think I'm grown a Coward, and begin to fear, my Heart beats faster than a Raw Soldier's in his first Engagement, or a Longing Maid in the Arms of a Man she likes, when Opportunity makes her. Fear. Sure it cannot be Clarinda.
Ha! By Heaven the very Crocodile. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: By all my hopes of Happiness the very Monster. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p: Madam, you are surpriz'd I believe, not to meet the Man you expected; I beg your Pardon for this Disappointment.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh. Indignation! No Sir I have met the Man I expected, though you are disappointed in your Woman.

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p: What does she mean!—Have you a Stratagem Madam, to bring you off,—come Ill help you; say, you happen'd into this Room by chance, and had no knowledge of the Plot, expected no Gallant.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh unheard of Impudence! a Gallant! No thou Monster of Ingratitude; have I refus'd all Mankind for thee? Nay, broke in upon the Rules of my Obedience, that I might keep my Faith Inviolate, and am I thus Rewarded? Is it not enough that you are False, and that I see you so, but you must add to your Barbarity, and throw a Scandal on my Fame, to hide your base Proceeding. Marry thee, No! From this Moment I resolve to hate thee, and to put it out of thy Power ever to deceive me a second time I'll Marry. Instantly. (Bellmein Peeping.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: I must hear how the Collonel succeeds in my Place.—

sp.speaker: Col. Man.
sp.p: It is enough I know thee guilty of that very Crime thou would'st impose on me; know that you writ to my Friend to come here with whom you have had many private Conferences, tho' I, Heaven knows, would not believe it, till my Eyes convinc'd me; but now thy Crimes are obvious to my Sight, and I take thee at thy word, and from this Moment I'll never see you more: Confusion on your Sex.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha, his Friend! what can he mean,—sure there's some Mistake in this, yet I cannot call him back.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: What have we Eves-droppers;—Oh Heavens! why was not you with my Cousin?

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: Hey day! why was not you with the Collonel?

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: Why, are not you the Collonel?

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: No faith, and now I begin to suspect you are not Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: you are in the Right indeed, I am not.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Heavens I'm undone, Manly's innocent.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: No, no Madam, I'll call my Friend back immediately, he shall beg Pardon upon the Spot,—Why, what a damn'd Mistake is here; faith he's gone, but here's an old Gentleman coming up.
sp.stage: [Goes to the Door, and returns quickly,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Lord, my Father, I'm undone if he finds a Man here; what shall I do? This was your Project, Emilia.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: Ha! 'Zdeath Madam where shall I run? For methinks I would not do any more Mischief, what shall I do Ladies?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Ha, a lucky thought comes into my Head; here, here, here, lie down upon this Mat.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: With all my Heart: Pox on't, to be thus put to't for nothing. If I had but got a Maidenhead, or made a Cuckold, it would not have vext me.
sp.stage: (Lies down, and they rowl him up.

div2.stage: Enter Careful, and tumbles over the Mat.

sp.speaker: Emil.
sp.p: There, there, lye still.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: A Pox on your Pride, we must have Matts with a Vengeance, but I'll turn over a new Leaf with this House I'll warrant you; I'll have no Matts, but such as lie under the Feather-Beds: Here I might have broke my Neck.
Toby, Sirrah, remove that Matt, and do you hear, throw it into the Horse-Pond; I'll have no more Mats in my House.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Matt, 'tis damn'd heavy; come out here, I believe the Dog is got into it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Lord, what shall I do? (aside.
sp.stage: [The Man goes to take up the Matt, and finds it heavy, shakes it and out drops Belimein.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: The Horse-pond! Nay then 'tis time to shift for my self.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Here, here, There's a Guinea for you Toby, bring him off some way or other.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Ha, what was that?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Bark Sir, bark; only the great Dog Sir was crept in the Matt.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: Wough, wough, wough, wough.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Rarely done; expect a better Reward for this, Toby.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: The Dog was it, I protest I thought it had been a Thief.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: No Sir, nothing else.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Why how now! Methinks you are mightily prink'd up. Mercy upon me, what a Bush of Hair is there fruz'd out; in my Conscience I believe you have got the Fore-top of some Beau's Wigg.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: That's the Fashion Uncle, you wou'd not have us dress like my Quaking Aunt that is to be. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: How now Sauce-box, your Quaking Aunt quotha.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you don't design to Marry that thing.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Thing do you call her? Icod you shall Marry Sir William immediately, or call that thing Mother, I can tell you, that.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh Heaven, what shall I do?

div2.stage: Enter Sir William, and Mrs. Plotwell.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Here Sir William, I give her to your Arms; I'll have my Coach harness'd, and to Church this Moment.

sp.speaker: Sir. Will.
sp.p: Madam tho' I don't pretend to be a Beau, yet I hope the World will distinguish the difference between a rough, unhewn Soldier, and a pollish'd Gentleman; I don't, in the least, hint at Manly.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Insipid Coxcomb. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: to Plot. For Heavens sake invent some way to give her an Hours time to consider, or she's undone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Friend shall I speak one word with thee.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: Twenty if you please.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Let me advise thee, do not be so passionate with thy Daughter, the little Discourse I had with her, shew'd her to be tractable; if thou think'st sit, Ill read her t'other Lesson upon her Duty, and I don't doubt but she'll comply.

sp.speaker: Care.
sp.p: With all my Heart; for whatever thou say'st, must be for her good, I'm convinc'd. Sir William we'll go take a Glass in the next Room till the Bride be ready, and then—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And then Madam I shall be the happiest Man alive; if I would change conditions with the Czar of Muscovy, may I be Condemn'd to the Smoak of Tobacco, and never know the Pleasure of taking Snuff.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: A very Courtly Wish indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Come, don't trifle away the time I have given you, but write to Manly, and beg him to Protect you, and Rescue you from the Arms of this Fool.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Oh how can I write to him, whom I have abus'd?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: And did not he pay you in the same Coin! Come, come, this little Mistake rather serves to encrease his Love than diminish it, when he finds you true, as no doubt but Bellmein has told him e're this, he'll be glad to accept the Conditions. Come, come, write to him Toper is within, and he shall carry it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well, it being my last Shift, I'll follow your Advice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Ay, ay, do so, I'll warrant you a Fortune, and the Od Man's Consent before I have done with him.

div2.stage: A Drum beating up for Volunteers. Bellmein crosses the Stage, and a Serjeant after him.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Captain, Captain.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: Ha, Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: I have got the finest Volunteer, a Beau, Captain.

sp.speaker: C. Cap.
sp.p: A Beau! Nay, if the Beaus begin to List, let the French look to't. Where is he Serjeant?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: He's coming Sir.

sp.speaker: C. Bell.
sp.p: I can't stay now, but I'll be here in a Moment, and I'll bring the Collonel with me.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: 'll wait you here Sir.
The Captain will be here in a Moment Sir; but pray Sir why will you go for a Soldier, Methinks you might get a Commission.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Because I dreamt Sir I should be a General,—and I have a a mind to rise gradually, I hate Jumping into Honour at once.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Sir I honour you; no doubt but you Dream will come true.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Sir I dreamt last Night that I saw two Armys join Battle, and mthought n the Scuffle my Brains was knock'd out, and when I'wak'd, I wonder'd to find my self with all my Limbs, I straight felt for my other Leg, and suspected my Eyes when they inform'd me I had both Hands.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: A very good Dream, and signifies your Advancement.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Nay, after that I had the strangest Dream, my Man found me Scaling my Curtains for a Fort, killing my Pillow, and entring Duel with my Breeches. Methought all the Trojan Faces in the Hangings were turn'd Frenchmen, and a Famine raging amongst 'em, they resolv'd to Eat me; so casting Dice what part of me to devour first, the ot fell upon my Head. Now Sir, all these Dreams I interpret quite contrary, I know I shall be a great Man.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: No, doubt on't Sir—I'm afraid all this Fellow's Courage lies in his Sleep. I'm resolv'd to sound him a little. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Prithee, Serjeant, tell me, what sort of a Thing a Camp is?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Why truly Sir, a Camp wou'd be a pleasant place, did the Fields produce Feather-beds; or if the Streams like those of the Golden Age! did run pure Wine; Or if Camp Meals woud Twelve and Seven observe due Hours!—But, Sir, starv'd on scarce fresh Green Sword, just so much Earth, to then to live the Life of Nature; Or as some do call it, The Life of the Hardy, to quench one's Thirst at the next Spring, up one's self each Night in Turff, and thence come sorth, like one of Soldiers, sown of Serpents Teeth, and Furrow, is a Course of Life, I fear, will never suit with your stitution.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: 'Tis something hard truly, but no matter, I'm resolvd.

sp.speaker: Sj.
sp.p: Oh! This is nothing Sir; here comes on a Troop, and you in Honour can't but lose an Eye; an Engine there goes off, and you will show your self a Coward, unless you lose an Arm—Here you are surrounded, and then 'twere base to bring more than one Sholder off.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: [Rubbing his Shoulder.] Ha! I don't like it. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Nay Sir, consider ere you go—For 'tis a danm'd Discredit to have a Nose after a Battle, or to walk the Streets upon your own Legs.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Humph!—I feel my self already partly compos'd of Flesh, partly of Wood. Methinks, I hang between two Crutches, like a Man in Chains, tost by the Wind, I don't like this Sliing into Reputation.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But these Men that you raise Serjeant, Are they to go against the French or Spaniards?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Why do you ask Sir?

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Because I cannot in Honour draw my Sword against the French.

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: How so, pray? You're no Jacobite, I hope.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p:
Oh! Sir, my Scruples are not founded upon Religion; but I'll tell you, the last Long Vacation, I made the Tour of Paris, where I receiv'd such extraordinary Marks of Civility from the French Court, particularly from the Duke of Berry, the Duke of Burgundy and the Duke—and from the Governour of Callis, such extravagant Obligations; But above all, from the Governour's Daughter—That upon my Soul, I cannot descend so far from the Punctilio's of
Honour, to go against 'em; But against Spain, I—Ha! the Coll. I'm resolv'd to fight him however, Death, Hell and Furies: Draw Sir!

sp.speaker: Cll.
sp.p: That I shou'd be such a Sot to believe her false. Oh! I'm undone, ruin'd beyond retrieving!

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Draw Sir, For what, Sir? [To Bell.]

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Sir, I say Draw Sir, or else resign all Pretensions to Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why what a Metamorphus is this? Is this your Voluntier, Serjant?

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but if you had not come as you did, he had been gone, for I found his Courage began to sink.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: To Clarinda! How dares such a Coxcomb as you Name Clarinda? [Draws and Disarms him.] Now learn more Wit, or get more Courage.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Courage, Sir, Z'death, Sir, I'll Box with you, [Pulling off his Neckcloth.] you have got my Sword, but no matter for that, I ll Fight it out at Fists; Lose a Fortune for want of Fighting, No!

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: I'll Box you, you Dog; give me the Cane, [To the Serjant.] Sirrah, I'll make Mummy of your Bones, I'll make you forswear sauntering after Fortunes, nay you shall not dare to look towards the House where they live, or so much as think of them.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Oh Lord Sir, for Heaven's sake! Sir, I'll observe the Conditions.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay now you are too rigid, I dare promise for Mr. Ogle.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: I will indeed Sir, only let me think of them, for who can help thinking, Sir—

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: No, here Serjeant, take this Fellow, and let him run the Gauntlet, I'll think you Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p: Oh Lord Sir! spare that, and I will not think of 'em upon my Faith, Sir.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Nay one thing more you must promise, which is, to resume your wnted Cowardice, and betake you to your Desk again. Go take Money of the Men you mean to Cozen; talk little, except when you are paid for't, 'tis an Antidote against Beating; keep your Hand from your Sword, and your Landresses Petticoats, and you'll live at peace.

sp.speaker: Og.
sp.p:
I will Collonel—Give me Wisdom that is beaten into a Man, for that sticks to him Egad. I'm wiser than a Justice of Peace; your Precepts are very learned, Sir. I'm your humble Servat—Farewel Sword, and welcom Tongue again. Now can't I
positively tell, whether 'tis best to be Couragious, or to have no Courage at all; Beaten if I Fight, and Beaten if I do not.—Now I think I know something of the Law, and yet if the Question was put to me I cou'd not Resolve it,

l.hi: But for my own part, I'll lay Courage down,
As all Men do, when they take up the Gown;
Cloak'd with the Law, I may securely aul,
And he that dares Affront me then, shall pay for all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

div2.stage: [Enter Toper, and gives the Coll. a Letter.]

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ha! Coll. Opportunly met, I bring an Express from the Queen of Beauty; her Orders are in that Paper.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Ha! 'Tis Clarindas hand— (reads) I hope by this time, you are satisfied of my Innocence, as I'm of yours; if not, I beg of you, by all the Tyes of Honour, to rescue me from this foolish Knight, to whom I am this Moment to be married by the rigid Command of my barbarous Father; and if I don't clear your Censures, use me as you please. Yours Clairnda—Rescue thee yes, the Fool shall quit all Pretensions to thee, unless this Arm deceive me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If it does Boy, here's another at thy Service.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: You may seise her at the End of the Street as she passes; Be sure you marry her as soon as you have got her; Let me alone to bring her Fortune, the Captain must help our Plot forward, as soon as he has help'd you, away with her—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With all my Heart, I love Mischief; I have a plaguy hankering Mind after this Cousin tho', e're since Manly told me she has Ten Thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: The Yoak shou'd be well lin'd, or 'twill sit very uneasy at best.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, there must be Gold proportionable to the Alloy, or 'twou'd not be current Coin, Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Well, I'm a good Natur'd Fellow now, to spend my time in your Business when I have an Assignation with one of the prettiest Girls about Town, Faith.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Some old o're worn Drab, I'll warrant, cast off by all the Beaus in Town, and now is become a new Face to the Drunkards.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: No Faith, she's a kept Mistriss, she Cost me not a Souce.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p:
Thou art still labouring between two Tides, Wine and Women:
Wilt thou never take up till thou art confin'd by a Doctor to dry Diet.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Dry Diet? You don't mean a Wife, I hope, catch me at that Meat and Choke me with it, that's just a Confinement to Sea-Bisuet at Land; tho' I'd do you all the Service I can, Collonel, in helping you to your Mistriss, yet I can't help lamenting the loss of a Friend.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Why will Matrimony lose me to my Friends? I shall love them as well as ever, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ay, but your Friends won't care that for you, [Snaping his Fingers.] for e're the second Bottle, you'll be calling, What's to pay? Your Wife won't go to Bed till you come Home; this makes Company uneasy, and what makes us uneasy decreases our Value fort; For my Part, I had rather be confin'd to Sea-Men in a Storm, or the Cant of a Conventicle, than the Company of a Married Man, for at every Mouse stirring, I shou'd think the Comforts of Matrimony was coming, with all its Commanding Retinue; A Wife, Egad I'd want Wine, the only Support of this Body.—

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Well, you declare for a Bottle, I for a Wife, which I think the greater pleasure far.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Where shall we find you?

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: At the Rose.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Adieu, Belmein shall come to you there.

l.hi: Let Fools be fetter'd to that Clog, a Wife,
Whilst free, I reap the Pleasure of my Life;
And Heaven grant I may no longer live,
Than I cn tst the Joys which Wine do's give.

sp.stage: A clash of Swords. Sir Will. cries Murder. Coll. and Cla, Bell, and Em. cross the Stage.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Haste, my Fairest, and let us tye that Knot, which nought but Death can lose.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Certainly, I heard Sir William's Voice cry [Ent. Sir Will.]. . What's the Matter Sir William? Where's my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Efeble me if I know; you had best send after her , or she'll be married to Manly, who drew upon me; and i I had t uitted her, he had run me quite thro' the Body, impair my Vgr.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p:
This was her Project of going on foot, she wou'd not have , under pretence of Notice being taken, forsooth; and
your Perswasion made me go before to get the Parson ready. Od's flesh, had I been there, this had not happen'd, old as I am, they shoud not have escapd so easily. Z'ath lt a Man take your Mistress from you In my Conscience, young Fllows are so rotten now a-days, they are afraid of every Suffle, lst they drop in pieces. Zounds, I cou'd curse the Minute I got this Bastard, to think what a Fortune she has lost. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Do you take my Breeding to have been at a Bear-garden, Sir, or in Bedlm, to endanger my Life for your Daughter. No, let her go, I'd marry an Acress sooner, and have more Hopes of her Virtue.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Say you so, Mr. Dity Crown? Adod, I cou'd find in my heart to dash the Powder out of your Whores Hair for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Your Age protects you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Well, if I dont sit the Baggage, I'm mistaken, Egad, I'll marry Toper's Niece immediately. [Enter Toper]
Mr. Toper, you came luckily; I am resolv'd to marry your Cousin this Moment. Ny Ill settle all I have upon her. I'll hamper my Daughter, I'll warrant her.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I came to inform you Sir, that I saw Coll. Manly and your Daughter enter the Church; the Parson met them at the Door, and I'm much afraid they will be married before you can get to 'em.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Let her marry and be pox't, Ill not give her a Farthing, I am resolvd. Let her go Soldiering with her Husband, and carry his Knap-sack, like a Trull as she is. If there be any Favour or Interest to be ad in an English Parliament, Ill have the Parson turn'd out of his place, for a Jcoite that coupled them.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: I have a Friend of mine at the Rose, just come from Oxford, If you please Mr. Caeul, I'll fetch him, and you may be marry'd in your own House.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: With all my heart. Adod, methinks I'm brisk and young again. This Audaious Wench▪
sp.l: My Blood boils high, and all my Spirits move.
Revenge gives Strength to Age as much as Love.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Well, my dearest Ann, I think my self the happiest Man alive since I espous'd thee: I have settld my whole Estate upon thee, which, with this Kiss I do confirm to thee again.

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Pray forbear Sir—

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: How Wife! Refuse to kiss me?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Yes, except a sweeter Air came from you—Faugh, you have turn'd my Stomach; I wonder you can ask me, knowing your Lungs are perish'd.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mercy upon me; Why, what have I married!—

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Here, Where are my Servants. [Ent. a Maid] Run to the Exchange, Fetch me a French Night-gown, and French Head; Set my Dressing-table in order, Do you hear? Let my Paint, Powder, and Patches be ready.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh lord! Paint, Powder, and Patches; Why, Hark y' Mistress, Are you not a Quaker?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: No Sir, I only made use of that Disguise to catch you in, but you have Money enough to equip me after the Fashion, and that was the only Motive of my Sanctity.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh! undone, undone!

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Look you Sir, I shall never endure your Conversation, I must have two Beds, two Chambers, and two Tables, it was an Article of our Agreement, you know, that I shou'd live retir'd—That is a-part Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: A curse on that Agreement—But hark y' Wife, you are not in Earnest sure?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: In earnest, Why, Do you think I jeast with Age?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: And you won't Bed with me?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Did ever Man of your Hairs ask such Questions? I vow I blush at your Unreasonableness.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: O Monstrous!—

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Is it fit I shou'd be bury'd? For to Bed with you were a direct Emblem of my going to my Grave!

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! Where is this Rogue, this Toper? What damn'd Succuus has he topt upon me?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: I'll have your Ficte st in my Wedding Ring, to put me in Mind of Mortality; Do you think Ill come within your winding Sheets! For what, to hear you art all night, and in the Morning find half my Husband on the Hangings—

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: I am married.

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Pray why did you marry? In my Conscience, you're as youthful as a Coffin, and as hot as the sultry Winter that froze over the Thames; they say the Hard Time did begin from you. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! I am made the Curse of all Mankind! O Patience! Patience!

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Your Humors comes frost from you, and your Nose has Isicles in Luna

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Hark y' Mistress, you that have a Feaver and Dog-days in your Blood; if you knew this, why did you marry me?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: That your experienc'd Aches, that have felt Springs and Falls these Forty Years, shou'd ask such a Question, as if I could not find Friends to supply your cold Defects; Do you think a Young Woman high in her Blood!—

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: And hot as Goats and Marmosets. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Apt to take slame, at any Temptation.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: And kindle at the Picture of a Man. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Wou'd wd Dust and Ashes, unless she were—

sp.speaker: Caref
sp.p: Crack'd, try'd, or broken up ha!

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Right Sir, or lack'd a Cloak.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mischief, and Hell, was there none to make your Cloak but me!

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Not so well lin'd Sir, Ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh! You staid for a wealthy Cuckold, did you?

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Your tame Beasts should have guilded Horns!—Besides Sir, I thought your Age wou'd wink at stolen Helps, if I took Comfort from abroad.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Yes, Yes, You shall have Comsomsort—I'll deliver Letters for you, or hold the Door!—

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: No Sir, Ill not give you that Trouble, I'll have a Maid shall do that— [Making a Courtesie.]

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh Impudence, unheard of Impudence!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: But, Sir. I look your Coffers shou'd maintain me at my Rate.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: How's that, pray?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Why like a Lady; I must have you Knighted, for I don't like Mistriss.—My Lady, wou'd sound better.

sp.speaker: Carf.
sp.p: Yes,—I shall rise to Honour.— [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I must have six Horses in my Coach, som are sit for those that have a Charge of Children, you and I shall never have any.

sp.speaker: Carf.
sp.p: If we have, all Middlesex will be their Fathers.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I'll have four Foot-Men, and this House clear'd of all this Old Lumber, and ainscotted, and lin'd with Looking-Glass, have , and China.

sp.speaker: Carf.
sp.p: Mercy upon me. ye, Mistriss, you told me you lov'd Retirement, hated Visits, and Bargaind for Hours of Devotion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Right, Sir, but what Woman speaks Truth before she's Married?

sp.speaker: Carf.
sp.p: Politickly Answer'd, and like one perfect in the sinning Trade.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Well, Sir, don't discompose your self, 'twill signify nothing, I'll in and examin your Jewels, chuse some for every Day, and some for Masques and Balls.

sp.speaker: Carf.
sp.p: The Devil go with you: Oh that I had my Daughter again! Two Days more of this, and I shall grow Mad, or to Redeem my self, dash out my Brains.

div2.stage: Enter on one side, the Coll. Clarinda, and Em. on the other, Bell and Toper.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: We have done your Business, Collonel, Bellemin here has tack'd 'em together.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I Canted out the Form of Matrimony as gravely as if I had taken my Degree at Edinborrough.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: And how does it take?

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Oh! Admirably Well, I listen'd a while, and sound she manag'd it rarely.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: She'll drive my Father out of his Wits.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Well, Captain, you'll observe what I told you, I'll follow you with another Project, I'll warrant you, will give the Old Fellow enough of Matrimony; Collonel, do you be ready when I call, to come in, do you hear? I fancy they are in such Confusion that it would be no hard Matter for all of you to get into the House unseen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: We'll endeavour it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But hark ye, Madam, there's something more to be said, before you and I part; Have you the Conscience to let your Friend launch into the Sea of Matrimony alone?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: To chuse, Sir, for if the Voyage prove Dang, on at a time is enough to be lost.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Would you have her Surrender upon the first Summons, Captain? You must expect some Fateague in Love, as well as War, the little disquiet of Hopes and Fears, do but enhan the Value of a Mistriss when gain'd; Soldiers and Knight Erra Court Danger and Despise an Enterprise that had no Difficulty .

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, if I had but the Hopes of a Carnival this Lent, 'twould be a sufficient Recompence, but Explation and Uncertainty, is the worst Food in the World for a Fellow of my Constitution.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Come, Madam, be Generous, you cannot have an Honester Fellow, I'll say that for him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Look ye there, Madam, he'll Vouch for me, if you don't think my own Word sufficient.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I shall trust no Bodies Judgment but my own, and that tells me, you are too much a Libertine for a Husband; why you have not the least Resemblence of a Lover.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No Resemblance! Why I am a perfect Skeleton, do but see how pale and wan I look! My Taylor shall Swear I am fall'n away six Inches in the Wast, since this Day seven Night, and if these be no Signs of being in Love, the Devil's in't.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Very violent Symptoms truly.—Have you any more of them, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Thousand; do but feel here the Palpation of my Heart, the Irregularity of my Pulse, the Immotion of my Brain.—In short, my whole Frame's disorder'd, and without immediate Help, I'm a Dead Man.—I'm quite out of Breath, I hope she won't put me to the expence of any more lyes, for certainly I have told enough to deserve any one Woman in Christendom. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman; Well, if your Distemper continues, I'll consult my Pillow for a Remedy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Take me with you to that Study, Madam, the sight of me there, will very much improve your Understanding. [Embracing her.]

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Come, I hope to see thee Blest as I am.—And now my Fairest, my whole Study shall be to make you Happy. [To Clarinda.]

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Madam, you had as good give me my Answer.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Not till I see the event of your Plot upon my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Come, come, she's thine Boy.

l.hi: For tho'-at first the Sex o're-shoot, deny.
Press 'em but home, and they will all comply.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mercy upon me! What shall I do?—Well thou'rt right enough serv'd, old Boy—Eh—Pox of thy old doating Head [beats his Head.] Thou must Marry for Revenge, must thou—I am reveng'd with a Witness—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant, I come Sir, to do you a piece of Service, if it be not too late; I heard just now, that one Toper had lodg'd a Woman, under pretence of a Cousin, in your House.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! I'm become the Town-talk already—Well Sir, and what then?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She's a common Strumpit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref
sp.p: How Sir! Have a care what you say.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll prove it Sir, she's of known Practice, the Cloaths she wears are but her Quarters Sins—She has no Lining but what she first offends for.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh! I sweat, I sweat.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, she has known Men of all Nations, and lain in by two Parts of the Map, Africa and America.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What ail you Sir, Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh undone! undone! I am married Sir

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay then, Heaven help you—Why wou'd you trust Toper, the debauchest Fellow in Town; she was once his Mistress; Money falling short, I suppose, he has topt her upon you, and is be maintain'd out of your Bags.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Oh! I have setl'd all I have in the World upon her, that damn'd Rascal. Oh that I cou'd see him stretch'd upon a Rack now, I'd give a thousand Pound for every Stretch that shou'd enlarge the Rogue thro' all his Joynts; that shou'd but show him Hell, and then recall his fleeting Soul, and give him strength to endure his Torment often. I'd have him as long a dying as a chop'd Eel.
sp.stage: [Enter two Footmen bearing in a Frame of a Picture, with a Curtain before it.]
sp.p: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My Lady has sent your Wife a Present Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Who is your Lady?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My Lady Manlove.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Pray what is it?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: A Picture for her Bed-chamber, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: For her Bed-chamber? There are but one sort of Pictures will please my Wife there—Pray draw back the Curtain.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: My Lady charg'd that none shou'd see it but your Wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Say you so Sir; but I will see it. [Draws the Curtain, and Toper comes out of the Frame.] Hell! and Damnation! Are you there, Bawd, Pander, Sirrah, I'll cut your Ears off.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold Sir, I must prevent your running into sarther Mischief; if you kill him the Law pursues you.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: The Law, who wou'd scruple Hanging to be reveng'd on such a Dog—Sirrah, you are a Villain—

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Sir, you are rude, and wou'd be beaten; can't a Man come in private, on Business to your Wife, but you must be inquisitive—

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Why this is beyond Example; Why do you hold me Sir? Z'death, I shall be Cuckolded before my face!

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ho! Are you come? I thought your Husband, to keep you chast, had set a Guard of Eunuchs over you, or shut you up in a Room, where no Male Beast is pictur'd, lest the sight of ought that cou'd beget, shou'd stir Desires, for I find he is as Jealous already as an Italian.

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: I wonder Sir, who licens'd you to pry, or spy out my Friends that come to me in private; it wou'd be more to your Reputation to trust to my Management, than to be peeping; but it shows your unbred Curiosity, which I shall correct.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Zounds! This is beyond the Suffering of a Saint; let me go, and I'll slit her Nose—Thou Woman double stampt.

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: You'll dare to break up Letters shortly, and examine my Taylor when he brings home my Gown, lest there be a Man in't. I'll have you to know Sir, I'll have whom I please, and when I please, and in what Disguise Iplease, and not have your sore Eyes so sawcy to peep, as if by Prevention, you meant to kill a Basilisk.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Mercy on me! I sall lose my Understanderstanding.

sp.speaker: M. Plot.
sp.p: Cousin Topez, I'll setch you the Hundred Pound immediately.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: A hundred Pound! Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I vow Sir, I am very much concern'd at your Misfortune, if I was in your place, I'd take my Daughter home; the Collonel is a Man of Honour, and will at least secure you from such Affronts as these.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Ah poor Girl! But I have not a Farthing to give her—This Woman has got all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Suppose Sir, I cou'd contrive a way to null your Marriage, Wou'd you forgive your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Caref,
sp.p: With all my Soul.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: What wou'd you give for such a Project, Ha?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: As much as I'd give to see you hang'd—Which is all I am worth—

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, Well, you wou'd forgive me too, wou'd you not?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Ay, tho' thou hadst murder'd my Father, and debauch'd my Mother.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Say you so Sir—Well, I will be with you in an instant.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: But which way will you do it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why you have not Consummated yet, have you?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: No, thank Heaven.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, then take you no Care; you'll give your Daughter the same Fortune you design'd for the Fop Knight?

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Ay, that I will, and 500 l. more.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come in Lovers, the Scene's chang'd.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Your Blessing, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And with it, your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: You have it, provided I get unmarried again.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We'll now call for your Lady; Oh, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Zounds, I Tremble at the Sight of her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: You shan't need Sir, for my Fury is over: I wish you Joy, Madam, and Sir I here resign you up your Settlement again.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: How's this? Ha, pray unfold this Mystery.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Why, Sir, this is Mrs. Pltwell, your Neighbour, who only put on this Disguise to be Serviceable to your Daughter—This honest Gentleman here, was the Parson that Coupled you.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.p: Now Sir. I think, I have kept my Word with y.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Why, truly Sir, being th to this thrown hd the Propct f sh a Worthy Collnl to you your Reason, and I don't own I have done you a piece of Service, in foring yo Family, and in his receiv'd .

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Tis now Madam, my my for this pay, which way I be Grateul.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: If I done Rwards it self; and if Mr. be over-paid.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: With all my Heart. I Frolick was a pretty Frolick—Now 'tis over.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I heard you was Married, Mr. Careful, I wish you Joy.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: You are mistaken, Sir William, 'tis my Daughter that is Married.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ha, the Collonel Married to my Misiress. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Sir William, I desire all Quarels between you and I may be Cancel'd.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Pray include me in that Treaty too, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Here has been strange juggling, Sir William, I have been Trick'd out of my Consent, I hope you'll Pardon me too.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I▪m in such Confusion, that I know not what to say, but I must show my Soul's above an Affront, and that nothing can disorder the Serenity of my Temper. [Aside.] Ay, we are all Friends, Gentlemen, and I forgive the Lady too, for she has done more honestly by me than most Women wou'd, she has Married the Man she lik'd, tho' 'tis the Fashion to take the Rich Husband they don't like, and make a Friend of the Man they do.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: One thing I desire you'd make clear to me, Madam, which is, Why did you give me Encouragment by your Woman?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I give you Encouragment by my Woman? What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I beg your . Madam, his Gold prevail'd upon me, and I thought what I sd would signify nothing, I hope you will forgive me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Never: Our of my Doors, I suppose thro' your managment, Ogle was so Familiar with me too.—Out of my Sight.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.p: Indeed, my Dear, I cannot Interceed in her behalf, since thro' her means my first Suspicion came, that made us both uneasy; but as to Ogle, I sufficiently Reveng'd your Quarrel, for I'll engage he never sets up for a Beau again.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Confound your whole Sex, you're all not worth a Gentleman's Anger; I'll to my Lodgings, and send for the Musick, and think no more of you nor Matrimony; if I do, I'll give 'em leave to ram me into a Hautboy and blow me out at the Holes; Impair my vigour.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Madam, What say you? Have you a mind to see me swing to Elizium in my Garters, and hear me sung about in a Ballad to a doleful new Tune, call'd, The Gentleman's Farewell to his unkind Lady—Or will you take Pity on me?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Well, Sir, to prevent such sad Disasters, I don't care if I give you my Hand, and as you deserve, my Heart shall follow.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ay, give me but the Body, and I'll warrant you I'll get the rest.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Hey day! What a Wedding chopt up there too! Well, I never shall believe common Report again, That all Women are Jacobites, since I find them so ready to Reward the Soldiers Service to the Nation with their Persons and Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I wish every Brave Man was Rewarded according to his Merit, I'm certain Captain Bellmein deserves more than I can give him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Don't Compliment your Husband, Madam, you don't know half my Deserts yet.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Brave Boys, brave Boys.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir here's the Musick without, come to Congratulate your Marriage.

sp.speaker: Caref.
sp.p: Bid 'em come in, we'll have a Dance.

sp.speaker: Top.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, I wish you Joy if there can be any such thing in a Wife; but for my part, it shall always be my Maxim not to part with my Liberty, till I can't help it; What Bird wou'd be confin'd to a Cage, when it can skip from Tree to Tree? Collonel, I'll come and take a Bottle with you by and by.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Madam, you deserve our best Thanks for this exemplary piece of Justice, and be assured, you have laid an eternal Obligation on me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: I am pleas'd that I have done you Service, and henceforth shall Devote my self to Virtue, and I hope Heaven will Pardon the Follies of my past Life.

l.hi: Blest in my Love, I Envy no Man's Fate,
Content alone, is the true happy State.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Plot.
sp.p: Virtue thou shining Jewel of my Sex—Thou precious Thing that none knows how to Value as they ought, while they Enjoy it, but like Spend-thrift Heirs, when they have wasted all their Store, wou'd give the World they cou'd retrieve their lost Estate: Therefore beware, you happy Maids, how you listen to the deluding Tongues of Men, 'tis only they have Power to betray you.

l.hi: Oh happy she, that can securely say
Folly be gone, I have no mind to Play,
My Fame is Clear, I have not Sinn'd to Day.

lg.l: YOƲ see, Gallants, 't has been our Poets Care
To shew what Beaux in their Perfection are,
By Nature Cowards, fooish, useles fools,
Made Men by Tayors, and by Women, Fools:
A Fckle, False, a Singing, Dancing Crew,
Nay now we hear they've Smiling Masters too;
Just now a Frenchman in the Dressing Room,
From Teaching of a Beau to Smile, was come,
He shew'd five Giea.—War'nt he rarely paid,
Thus all the World by Smiles are once betray'd;
The States Man Smiles on them he wou'd Undo,
The Courtier's Smies are very seldom True,
The Lovers Smiles too many do believe,
And Women Smile on them they wou'd Deceive;
When Trades-Men Smile, they safely Cheat with Ease,
And Smiling Lawyers never fail of Fees.—
The Doctor's Look the Patient's Pain beguiles,
The Sick Man lives. if the Physician Smiles:
Thus Smiles with Interest hand in hand do go,
He surest Strikes, that Smiling gives the Blow;
Poets, with us, this Proverb do Defy,
We live by Smiles, for if you Frown we die.
To Please you then shall be our chief Endeavour,
And all we ask, is but your Smiles for Ever.
Hold—I forget, The Author bid me say,
She humbly begs Protection for her Play:
'Tis Yours—She Dedicates, it to you all,
And sure you're too Gen'rous, to let it fall;
She hopes the Ladies will her Cause Maintain,
Since Virtue here has been her only Aim.
The Beaux, she thinks, won't fail to do her Right,
Since here they're taught with safety how to Fight.
She's sure of Favour from the Men of War,
A Soldier is her Darling Character;
To fear their Mrmrs then wou'd be absurd,
They only Mutiny when not Prefer'd:
But et, I see, she does your Fury dread,
And like a Prisoner, stands with fear half Dead,
While you are Judges, do her Sentence give,
you're not pleat'd, she says she cannot live.
Let my Petition then for once prevail,
And let your gen'rous Claps her Pardon Seal.
